abstract.p: This study tested the appropriateness of unified glare rating (UGR), CIE glare index (CGI), British glare index (BGI), and visual comfort probability (VCP) for evaluating discomfort glare from common non-uniform electric light sources. An experiment was conducted in a windowless room. High dynamic range photogrammetry was used for measuring three non-uniform fluorescent glare sources. The luminance and geometry data were acquired to calculate the glare ratings. The sub-divisibility and additivity of UGR, CGI, BGI, and VCP were tested via numerical method. Their predictability was evaluated using 67 subjects in two sessions. It was found that UGR, CGI, BGI, and VCP all have valid additivity, but only UGR and CGI have valid sub-divisibility. Current formulae of UGR, CGI, BGI and VCP all overestimate the glare sensation from non-uniform sources that young people may feel.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: In reality, non-luminous and light-emitting surfaces are rarely uniform. When people perceive non-uniform light, they may feel discomfort glare from the high dynamic range of luminance or extreme variation.1 Since 1925, many researchers have attempted to quantify discomfort glare.2–7 Unfortunately, the physiological and psychophysical mechanisms of discomfort glare are not yet well understood.8 As a result, different glare indices have been individually developed in four fields to evaluate interior electric lighting,9–27 daylighting (windows),28–37 exterior area lighting,38–40 and roadway and traffic lighting.41–45

In particular, for evaluating interior electric lighting, Guth9 developed an index called visual comfort probability (VCP), based on the borderline between comfort and discomfort brightness (BCD),10 (Equation (1)). VCP is calculated using Equations (2)–(5) for single or multiple light sources.8,11–13,16 Note that in Equation (2), a glare source needs a solid angle subtense, ω of at least 0.0000002924 sr, otherwise, the calculated glare sensation value M could be negative.8 In the UK, based on the work of Hopkinson,17,18 the British glare index (BGI)19 was adopted in 1985, calculated using Equation (6), also called the BRS equation,20 for evaluating single or multiple light sources. Meanwhile, two more indices were developed independently, including St, (Equation 7), and MUSSR (Equation 8).19

For quantifying discomfort glare sensation from a single light source, the formulae of VCP, BGI, St, and MUSSR share a standard form as M=(La·ωb)/(Lbc·pd) with varying exponents a, b, c, and d.8 Without further experiments, the Commission Internationale de l'Eclairage (CIE) consolidated them via mathematical manipulation to eliminate their weaknesses but retain their advantages, and proposed the CIE glare index (CGI), (Equation (9)), and the unified glare rating (UGR), (Equation (10)).8,11–13,19,21–24 Only UGR has been globally adopted mainly due to its simplicity rather than accuracy.21,25,26 Later, CIE27 modified Equation (10) as UGRsmall (Equation 11) to correct its overestimation for small electric light sources (projected area < 0.005 m2). When developed, those glare indices (VCP, BGI, St, MUSSR, CGI, UGR, UGRsmall, and GGR) did not take a possible non-uniform light distribution into account. A root cause of this oversight is the lack of an efficient method for measuring non-uniform light distributions.46 Conventional luminance meters have low measurement resolution because of their tedious point-by-point process. No way could the non-uniform luminous elements of a glare source, which produce the discomfort sensation, be identified using a luminance meter. This limitation was recognized by some and to overcome it a stereo-luminance-meter was proposed.47,48 Unfortunately, no satisfactory results were achieved in these studies.

To bridge this research gap, the author recently developed high dynamic range (HDR) photogrammetry,49 which uses a single consumer grade digital camera, fitted with a standard, wide-angle, or fisheye lens, to measure per-pixel synchronous luminance and geometry data across a scene. Depending on the pixel resolution of the camera sensor, millions of data points can be acquired at a single measurement. HDR photogrammetry could largely facilitate the evaluation of discomfort glare caused by common non-uniform light sources.

As the first step to that end, this study looked into the appropriateness of the widely used UGR, CGI, BGI, and VCP methods for evaluating interior electric lighting installations. UGR, CGI, BGI, and VCP were developed based on meter measurements of assumed uniform light distributions but are used in practice for evaluating common non-uniform light sources by simply treating them as uniform. With aid of HDR photogrammetry, a numerical method was used to test the validity and predictability of UGR, CGI, BGI, and VCP for evaluating non-uniform electric light sources.

sec.title: 2. Research problems
sec.p: Sub-divisibility and additivity of glare sensation are the foundation of all discomfort glare indices. The argument of sub-divisibility is that if a single large source is divided into multiple subsections for facilitating the glare calculation, it should yield the same value for any number of sub-divisions. Likewise, for additivity, if multiple discrete light sources are assessed individually for an additive discomfort glare, they should yield the same glare rating as if they are assessed simultaneously as a whole, independent of any additions. In particular, additivity of glare sensation is important for summation of multiple glare sources over the field of view (FOV) to approximate the actual discomfort feeling of an observer. Whenever an observer’s eyes are exposed to multiple discrete glare sources, at that moment, he/she perceives all glare sources simultaneously as a whole, as part of his/her vision (often binocular), not sequentially one by one as the traditional glare calculation assumed without experimental verification. Even when the observer looks at any individual glare source, other glare sources in the periphery contribute to his/her glare feeling.

Although Einhorn50 treated them as no different, sub-divisibility and additivity of glare sensation are actually not the same, due to two practical concerns. First, sub-divisions are mainly used for facilitating the evaluation of a single non-uniform glare source via numerical analysis, for example, with aid of HDR photogrammetry,49 while the glare addition has been commonly used for evaluating multiple discrete glare sources. Second, the additive process, which relies on the physical existence of multiple discrete sources, is not simply the reverse of dividing a single non-uniform source into multiple imaginary subsections, which could be either indistinct or distinct, depending on how the sub-divisions are obtained for benefit of the numerical analysis.

In the formulae of CGI and UGR, the exponent of the solid angle ω that glare sources subtend to an observer’s eyes was set at unity by CIE, without any experimental validation, to obtain mathematical consistency for valid additivity and sub-divisibility.50 Actually, ω1 solely may not guarantee the mathematical consistency in the addition and sub-division of glare sensation, which is expressed as ∑(Ls2ω/p2). The Guth position index p cannot be overlooked, which co-varies with the solid angle ω of different targets. The transformation of 10log(L1.6ω0.8/p1.6)=8log(L2ω/p2), claimed by Einhorn50 as evidence of the proportionality to solid angle ω1, did not account for the addition and sub-division of glare sensation, since 10log(∑(L1.6ω0.8/p1.6).)≠8log(∑(L2ω/p2)). In fact, ω1 was not adopted in most previous experimental results. For example, BCD uses ω−0.21, VCP uses both ω1 and ω0.2, BGI uses ω0.8, St uses ω0.4. Only MUSSR uses ω1. It is not justified to modify the formulae derived from experimental results for assumed sub-divisibility and additivity of glare sensation, simply based on the proportionality to solid angle ω1 without experimental validation.

On the other hand, conventional discomfort glare calculations often assumed common non-uniform light surfaces as uniform, whose luminance value L was determined via the luminous intensity Ιγβ in the direction of an observer’s eyes divided by the projected area Ap of the target (i.e., L=Iγβ/Ap)19 The effect of the luminance of the background, excluding the glare sources, on glare was also indirectly assessed using a vertical illuminance (Ei) measured at the observer’s eyes. With aid of HDR photogrammetry, such limitations rooted in non-uniform luminance measurement no longer exist.

In addition, CGI and UGR were mathematically manipulated by CIE to achieve the simplicity and practicability desired for a global glare index. Some factors, such as direct illuminance Ed and field luminance Lf, were dropped without experimentation. Such modifications to get around the limitations of conventional meters for measuring non-uniform light may have biased the glare calculations of real “complex sources,” such as parabolic louvered fluorescent luminaires which have numerous tiny luminous elements formed by glazing materials and control elements into non-uniform patterns with irregular shapes. Binning “complex sources” into sub-groups quantified with different formulations, as UGR does,27 is unrealistic given the wide variety of such “complex sources” in the market, and thus, would be impractical.

Then, can UGR, CGI, BGI, or VCP be used for evaluating common non-uniform electric light sources via additivity and sub-divisibility? The answer is unknown without testing the validity and predictability of those indices in experiments, and then comparing the calculated glare ratings to subjective predictions using a large number of human subjects.

sec.title: 3. Rating scales of VCP, BGI, CGI, and UGR
sec.p:
This study first looked into the rating scales of VCP, BGI, CGI, and UGR. The semantic differential scales of BGI, CGI, and UGR used by different researchers are summarized in Table 1. Values of UGR range from 10 (imperceptible) to 34 (intolerable), with a three-unit step for an easily perceptible difference.8,11–13,51–54 The cognate CGI shares a rating scale 10–34, based on the CIE-11721 and Figures B4 and B5 in the CIE-055.19 On UGR or CGI, a rating value of 19 (just acceptable) is often interpreted as the borderline between comfort and discomfort glare.21,35 Yet Fisekis et al.35 and Akashi et al.55 shifted the rating scale of UGR by three units down, that is, from 7 (imperceptible) to 31 (intolerable). This shifted scale was not adopted in this study. Table 1

Table 1 also lists the ratings of BGI (also called IES glare index) in value from 10 (just perceptible) to 28 (just intolerable), as used in the literature.32,35,51 CIE confirmed the major range of interest of BGI is from 10 to 26, without any clear semantic differential scale being disclosed.19 Yet Boyce claimed a range of BGI from 10 (imperceptible glare) to 30 (very uncomfortable glare).8 This study followed the majority and adopted the rating scale of BGI from 10 (just perceptible) to 28 (just intolerable), with an extended range of 7 (imperceptible) and 31 (intolerable) by following the three-unit step.

The rating scale of VCP has possible values from 0% to 100%.52 The range of VCP of interest is from 20% to 85%,19 while 70% is widely accepted as the threshold for not feeling any discomfort glare.8 Based on Figures B4 and B5 of CIE-055,19 approximately, a VCP value of 36% is “just uncomfortable”, 50% is “just acceptable”, 65% is interpreted as between “perceptible” and “just perceptible”, and 75% is “imperceptible”. The CIE19 proposed a fair correlation between VCP and BGI (range 10–26) as equation (13) (i.e., equation B2 in CIE-055). Mistrick and Choi52 also proposed equation (14), which predicts VCP values within a range from UGR = 14 (between “just perceptible” and “perceptible”) to approximately UGR = 22 (unacceptable). As shown in Figure 1, the two lines of VCP-CIEB2 and VCP-CIE055 intersect at “just uncomfortable” (VCP = 36%). At the higher end of the scale (imperceptible), the line of VCP-CIE055 agrees with the threshold value of 70% for no discomfort glare,8 but the line of VCP-CIEB2 underestimates the glare sensation. sec.title: 4. Experiments
sec.p: Two laboratory experiments were carried out in a windowless room in the Department of Building Services Engineering at the Hong Kong Polytechnic University in Hong Kong. The first experiment tested the sub-divisibility and additivity of UGR, CGI, BGI, and VCP, with aid of HDR photogrammetry.49 The second experiment tested the suitability of UGR, CGI, BGI, and VCP for evaluating non-uniform electric light sources, by comparing to subjective evaluations.

sec.title: 4.1. The first experiment
sec.p:
The windowless room is 7.70 m long, 6.85 m wide and 2.50 m high, with a layout of typical classroom furniture. A digital camera Canon EOS Rebel XT fitted with Sigma zoom lens 10–20 mm F4-5.6 EX was used. Table 2 summarizes the optimal features of the camera and lens identified in an earlier study.56 To simulate the binocular vision of human eyes, which have a FOV of 120° (width) × 135° (height),57 the largest angle of view 102.4° (circular)58 was used at the shortest focal length f = 10 mm of the Sigma zoom lens 10–20 mm F4-5.6 EX for the HDR photogrammetry. Although the FOV of the binocular vision is a little larger than that of the camera lens, contributions outside the optical field are minimal.59,60 As shown in Figure 2, the camera was mounted on a tripod at one end of the training room, at the original point (0, 0, 0) of the XYZ coordinates. A computer software program DSLR remote Pro was used for remote control of the camera. Figure 2

Three typical parabolic louvred fluorescent luminaires G1, G2, and G3 were track-mounted on the ceiling and served as the non-uniform glare sources. This type was identified in a field survey in a total of 29 classrooms, offices, and library spaces at the Hong Kong Polytechnic University. Each luminaire was fitted with two fluorescent T5 lamps (Osram FH 35 W/840, 4000 K). The light-emitting surfaces of G1, G2, and G3 were almost flat, with a square area of 0.234 m2 (1.460 m × 0.160 m). As shown in Figure 2, G1 was tilted 38° while G2 and G3 were both tilted 30°, facing the camera. Note that this experimental setup may not be a typical lighting condition in daily life. Rather, by tilting the glare sources toward the camera and later on the human subjects, this study emphasized an exaggerated discomfort glare problem from non-uniform light sources in a well-controlled laboratory setting.

The centre of G1 (−2.030, 5.411, 1.080 m), G2 (0.745, 5.411, 1.080 m), and G3 (2.215, 3.101, 1.080 m) was offset 23.4°, 13.7°, and 39.8°, respectively, from the aiming line of the camera. The perpendicular distance from the light-emitting surfaces of G1, G2, and G3 to the camera was measured as 4.112 m (G1), 3.593 m (G2), and 2.433 m (G3), respectively. The incident angles from the camera to the centre of G1, G2, and G3 were calculated as 44.8°, 51.6°, and 52.2°, respectively. The projected areas of the light-emitting surfaces were calculated as 0.166 m2 of G1, 0.145 m2 of G2, and 0.143 m2 of G3, which all fall in the range of 0.005–1.5 m2 without overestimation or underestimation of UGR.27 The original aluminium parabolic louvres of G1, G2, and G3 had very uneven specular light distributions. The parabolic louvers were replaced with translucent paper to cover the whole light-emitting surface of G1, G2, and G3 for a less non-uniform light output, which were tested separately, as a control situation for comparison. The non-uniformities of the louvred and paper-covered G1, G2, and G3 luminaires were measured using HDR photogrammetry, as discussed later.

Twelve ceiling recessed parabolic-louvred troffers (2 × T8, Philips TLD 58 W/840 CE, 4000 K) provided two ambient light levels tested in the experiment. As shown in Figure 2, all of the nine troffers mounted in front of the camera were fully shielded to preclude any direct glare to the lens or later eyes of human subjects. High ambient light was provided by all 12 troffers, while low ambient light was provided by only four of them, shown as the shaded ones in Figure 2. When G1, G2, and G3 were turned off to exclude light from these glare sources adding to ambient light, the vertical illuminance Ei received at the camera lens was measured as 137.4 lx under high ambient light, and 51.4 lx under low ambient light. Based on the finding that higher ambient light improves the quality of HDR images,56 the parabolic louvred G1, G2, and G3 luminaires were tested at high ambient light, while the translucent paper covered surfaces were tested at low ambient light level, as a control situation of more uniform sources.

The XYZ coordinates of three reference points on the light-emitting surfaces of G1, G2, and G3 were physically measured in the laboratory using a laser distance meter and a roll tape measure. As shown in Figure 2, P1 (−1.277, 5.401, 1.112 m) was used for G1, P2 (0.018, 5.395, 1.063 m) for G2, and P3 (1.479, 3.101, 1.070 m) for G3. Note that only one reference point was used for calibrating each luminous surface, rather than three as required in the literature,49 since orientations of the light-emitting surfaces of G1 (yaw angle θ = −0.3°, pitch angle τ = 52°, and roll angle ρ = −0.7°), G2 (θ = 0.1°, τ = 60°, ρ = −0.2°), and G3 (θ = −0.2°, τ = 60°, ρ = 0.3°) had already been measured in the room. The polarity of θ, τ, and ρ follow the right hand rule.49

Viewing materials were attached on an A2 size black foam board. One foam board was mounted on the back wall of the room. Another duplicate foam board was mounted in the middle of the room close to the aiming line of the camera. Viewing targets included 12 grey-scaled checkers in the middle and four grey blocks (RGB = 140) at the four corners.61 Luminance values of the four calibration blocks were physically measured in the field for photometric calibration of raw HDR images later. As shown in Figure 2, the camera was focused on the centre of the foam board mounted on the back wall, as were the eyes of human subjects during the subjective evaluation. The focusing distance of the camera was 5.871 m. The aiming direction of the camera was measured as (yaw angle κ = −1.1°, pitch angle η = 0°, roll angle ϕ = 0°) in terms of the coordinates Z, X, and Y, respectively, following the right hand rule for polarity.49 The middle foam board was used for calibrating HDR images and explanations to the participants in the subjective evaluation.

As listed in Table 3, a total of eight trials were conducted for acquiring the luminous elements of G1, G2, G3, separately and jointly at the two ambient light levels. Session I, which included Trials 1–4 for testing the translucent-paper-covered G1, G2, and G3, had the low ambient light (Ei = 51.37 lx). Session II, which included Trials 5–8 for testing the parabolic-louvred G1, G2, and G3, had the high ambient light (Ei = 137.38 lx). Within each session, the four different trials shared a constant ambient light Ei. At each trial, the direct vertical illuminance Ed was also measured at the lens of the camera (or later on eyes of the observer). Ed took all light sources into account, including (a) the ceiling recessed troffers that provided the ambient light and (b) glare sources G1, G2, and G3. The CIE19 stated that the luminance of a glare source must be greater than 500–700 cd/m2 for producing a discomfort glare sensation. Therefore, to be conservative, this study adopted a threshold value of 500 cd/m2 to identify all glaring luminous elements on G1, G2, and G3. Values of all glaring luminous elements over the FOV were then extracted from each HDR image of the test scene. It was found that all glaring luminous elements producing glare sensation were distributed solely on the light-emitting surfaces of G1, G2, and G3.

For the non-uniform distribution of the glaring luminous elements on both louvred and paper-covered G1, G2, and G3, the statistics are summarized in Table 4. The louvred G1 had a luminance range of 501.2–25650.7 cd/m2 with a min/max ratio of 0.0195. The louvred G2 had a range of 501.0–27977.7 cd/m2 with a min/max ratio of 0.0179. Aided by the HDR photogrammetry,49 besides the luminance values, the coordinates XYZ in the field of every single luminous element on the light-emitting surfaces of G1, G2, and G3 could be converted from their pixel coordinates xz on the HDR image. The luminance and geometric data were then extracted to calculate glare ratings of UGR, CGI, BGI, and VCP, via numerical analysis. Detailed data analyses are introduced later.

sec.title: 4.2. Subjective assessment
sec.p: Next, subjective assessments of the discomfort glare from the non-uniform G1, G2, G3 luminaires were carried out in the same room. The subjective evaluations were divided into two sessions, 20 minutes each, carried out on different dates. As listed in Table 3, Session I covered Trials 1–4, where paper-covered G1, G2, G luminaires were tested at low ambient light level (Ei = 51.37 lx). Session II covered Trials 5–8 for testing louvred G1, G2, G3 luminaires at high ambient light level (Ei = 137.38 lx). Subjects were recruited from the Hong Kong Polytechnic University and nearby neighbourhoods. All subjects were screened upon arrival for normal eyesight (i.e., minimum Snellen acuity 20/20, corrected or not) and normal color vision. Only qualified subjects participated in this study. Participants were aged 18 to 38 years, average 25.6 years old. Most of them were college students. A group of 67 subjects (47 males, 20 females) participated in Session I. Another group of 67 subjects, including 43 males and 24 females, most of them returned from the first session, participated in Session II.

Each participant was sitting on an adjustable chair behind a table with his/her eyes located approximately at the same location and height as those of the camera, which was removed. Participants used their binocular vision for evaluating the discomfort glare. Before starting, each participant was asked to spend 5 minutes to read and sign the consent form put on the table, ask any questions and listen to the explanations. During the 5 minutes, the participant was instructed not to look at any glare sources G1, G2, and G3, so his/her eyes could be fully adapted to the general lighting in the room. Once started, the participant was instructed to always focus his/her eyes on the centre of the foam board attached on the back wall, which is perpendicular to his/her sightline, while feeling the discomfort glare from G1, G2, and G3 off axis. There was no time limitation for this evaluation process. The subject took as long time as he/she might need to confidently rate the discomfort glare sensation.

At each trial, the participant was asked to rate the discomfort glare sensation, based on his/her own experiences in daily life. The experimenter had explained in detail to the subjects in advance about the meaning and sequence of the words used to describe the glare scale (i.e., imperceptible, just perceptible, perceptible, just acceptable, unacceptable, just uncomfortable, uncomfortable, just intolerable, and intolerable). In addition, to eliminate the possible confusions a participant might have about the different semantic rating scales used by different glare indices (i.e., 10–34 for UGR and CGI, 7–31 for BGI, 75–12 for VCP), this study used a temporary semantic scale t = 0–8 (0 = imperceptible, 1 = just perceptible, 2 = perceptible, 3 = just acceptable, 4 = unacceptable, 5 = just uncomfortable, 6 = uncomfortable, 7 = just intolerable, 8 = intolerable). This linear rating scale t can be converted to the semantic scales of UGR/CGI, BGI, and VCPCIE055, as listed in Table 1, using Equations (15), (16), and (17). At the first trial, G1, G2, and G3 were all switched on to form the lighting condition seen when the participant came in. At the follow-up three trials in each session, G1, G2, and G3 were gradually switched off, one at each trial in a random order to mitigate the impact of eye fatigue and off-axis viewing angle on discomfort glare sensation. This arrangement could also avoid restrike of the fluorescent lamps. In each session, the ambient light remained unchanged during all four trials. Subjective assessments recorded on paper forms were collected at the end of the experiment. The data were further analysed as described in Section 6.3 and compared to the predictions of UGR, CGI, BGI, and VCP.

sec.p: Data treatment started from the photometric calibration of the raw HDR images in Radiance. First, the vignetting effect V(v) of the test rig (Canon EOS Rebel XT fitted with Sigma lens 10−20 mm F4−5.6 EX) at focal length 10 mm and aperture f/5.6, which drops luminance gradually from the optical centre to the periphery, was corrected using Equation (18) (v = 0°–50°).56 Second, from the calibration grey checkers at the four corners of each foam board, a calibration factor CF (CF = Lmeasured/LHDR) was obtained using physically measured luminance values (Lmeasured) and those (LHDR) retrieved from the raw HDR images. sec.title: 5.4. Calculating discomfort glare ratings using numerical method
sec.p: The acquired synchronous luminance values (≥500 cd/m2) and XYZ coordinates of all glaring luminous elements on the light-emitting surfaces of G1, G2, and G3 were then used to calculate their discomfort glare ratings using VCP, BGI, CGI and UGR. The conventional calculation of discomfort glare by these methods considers only uniform light surfaces so this is not appropriate. Alternatively, each glaring luminous element at the pixel level could be technically treated as uniform, so per-pixel numerical analysis was conducted in Excel for the calculation.

First, for each glaring luminous element, its projected area and solid angle subtended to the camera were calculated using Equations (24), (25), and (26). sec.title: 6. Validation of UGR, CGI, BGI, and VCP
sec.p: To validate UGR, CGI, BGI, and VCP for evaluating discomfort glare from common non-uniform electric light sources, their sub-divisibility, additivity, and predictability of discomfort glare sensation were tested sequentially.

sec.title: 6.1. Testing sub-divisibility
sec.p:
A numerical method was used to test the sub-divisibility of UGR, CGI, BGI, and VCP for evaluating non-uniform glare sources. The maximum number of sub-divisions is the number of glaring luminous elements at pixel level on each luminous surface of G1, G2, or G3. To test the sub-divisibility, fewer sub-divisions are needed. The glaring luminous elements were then binned according to their luminance values. Since more glaring luminous elements have lower luminance values, an arbitrary multiplier 1.1 was used for gradually increasing the width of each luminance span, starting at 500 cd/m2. For example, 500–550 cd/m2, 550–605 cd/m2, and so on, till the maximum 27977.7 cd/m2 across the scene is covered in the 43 rd sub-division (27 382–30 120 cd/m2). Adjacent luminance bins in order were further grouped into fewer sub-divisions. As shown in Table 6, the glaring luminous elements on each light-emitting surface of G1, G2, G3, or G1G2G3 jointly were divided into six levels of sub-divisions. For example, louvred G1 (501.2–25650.7 cd/m2) could have N = 1, 3, 7, 21, 42, and 15 249 sub-divisions. Table 6

Derivation of Equation (31) was based on the additive luminous intensity (I=L·A), which is the product of luminance (L) in a given direction and the projected area (A). The glare centre (Xc, Yc, Zc) of this sub-division was calculated as the average XYZ coordinates of every single pixel (Xi, Yi, Zi) weighted by its glare sensation Gi. The calculated values of UGR, CGI, DGI and VCP are shown in Figure 4 plotted against different numbers of sub-divisions, from unity to the total number of pixels. Note that for VCP, glare ratings of the luminous surfaces of G1, G3, and G1G2G3 jointly were not calculated at pixel level because the outcomes indicated negative glare sensations.

To validate the sub-divisibility, those data shown in Figure 4 were further analysed in SPSS using a one-way ANOVA test. The proposed null hypothesis was that the sub-divisibility of glare sensation of VCP, BGI, CGI, and UGR holds. The difference between glare ratings calculated at different numbers of sub-divisions (from unity to discrete pixels) was based on an average (mean) value of G1, G2, G3, and G1G2G3 jointly, which had louvred or paper-covered luminous surfaces under two ambient light levels. The calculated p-values for UGR (p = 0.931, 0.941) and CGI (p = 0.919, 0.921) in both sessions are all larger than 0.05, while the p-values for BGI (p = 0.033, 0.015) and VCP (p = 0.000, 0.000) are all less than 0.05. Statistically, if the p-value < 0.05, the between-group difference is significant, corresponding to a 5% chance of rejecting the null hypothesis. In other words, using different levels of sub-divisions of the same glare source(s) significantly changed the glare rating calculated via the numerical method, thus, the sub-divisibility does not hold. Otherwise, if the p-value ≥ 0.05, the between-group difference is insignificant so the sub-divisibility holds. Conclusively, UGR and CGI have valid sub-divisibility of glare sensation, but BGI and VCP do not.

sec.title: 6.2. Testing additivity
sec.p: Additivity is not a new research problem and was considered important by past researchers such as Einhorn.50 Additivity of glare sensation from multiple discrete glare sources over the FOV approximates the actual discomfort feeling of an observer. With additivity, if multiple discrete light sources are assessed individually and then added together (as in the traditional additive glare calculation), they should yield the same glare rating as if they are assessed simultaneously as a whole. This was one of the reasons why CIE19,21 changed the power indices of Ls and ω in the UGR. The formulae for UGR, BGI, CGI, and VCP, including the equations to calculate the position index p, may or may not show the addivitiy of glare sensation. The traditional glare calculations assumed additivity without testing them.

This study then tested the additivity of UGR, CGI, BGI, and VCP for evaluating non-uniform discrete glare sources. Per-pixel numerical analyses were again used. For addition of any two (i.e., G1 and G2; G1 and G3; or G2 and G3) or three glare sources (i.e., G1, G2, and G3), the calculated glare ratings before the addition were compared to those with addition. If there is no significant difference, additivity holds. First, the discrete glare sources were treated as a bunch of pixels at one glare centre (addition number N = 1) for calculating the glare rating before the addition. Then, the additive glare ratings (N = 2, or 3) from the discrete glare sources with individual glare centres were calculated for comparison. Following the procedure and equations given in Section 5.4, the calculated values are illustrated in Figure 5.

The data illustrated in Figure 5 were further analysed with SPSS to test the additivity of the glare sensation of UGR, CGI, BGI, and VCP. The proposed null hypothesis was that the additivity of glare sensation of VCP, BGI, CGI, and UGR holds. The means of values of UGR, BGI, CGI, and VCP were compared via one-way ANOVA at different number of additions (N = 1, 2, and 3). The calculated p-values for UGR (p = 0.088), CGI (p = 0.291), BGI (p = 0.467), and VCP (0.515) at all eight trials are all larger than 0.05, which indicates that there is no significant difference between these additions. It is concluded that UGR, CGI, BGI, VCP all have valid additivity of glare sensation.

sec.title: 6.3. Testing predictability
sec.p: The subjective response of discomfort glare varied greatly in this experiment. In terms of the temporary semantic scale t (i.e., 0 = imperceptible, 1 = just perceptible, 2 = perceptible, 3 = just acceptable, 4 = unacceptable, 5 = just uncomfortable, 6 = uncomfortable, 7 = just intolerable, 8 = intolerable), the average subjective rating was 3.2 within a 95% confidence interval (CI) of 0.33 and a standard deviation (σ) of 1.4 for evaluating the paper-covered G1G2G3 jointly. The subjective ratings for paper-covered G1, G2, and G3 were 3.4 with 95% CI of 0.41 and σ of 1.7, 3.3 with 95% CI of 0.35 and σ of 1.4, and 3.3 with 95% CI of 0.45 and σ of 1.9, respectively. Likewise, for evaluating the louvered G1G2G3 jointly, G1, G2, and G3, the subjective ratings were 3.3 with a 95% CI of 0.38 and σ of 1.6, 2.7 with a 95% CI of 0.35 and σ of 1.5, 3.4 with a 95% CI of 0.36 and σ of 1.5, 2.4 with a 95% CI of 0.42 and σ of 1.7, respectively. Using Equations (15), (16), and (17), the subjective glare ratings of UGR, CGI, BGI, and VCP were also obtained. Figure 6 shows all subjective discomfort glare ratings, with a 95% confidence level, of the paper-covered or louvred G1, G2, G3, and G1G2G3 jointly at all eight trials.

Such CIs indicate the large differences of glare perception from non-uniform sources between human subjects. Similar variations were also reported in the literature. For example, Eble-Hankins and Waters13 reported a standard deviation 3.4%–16.6% of the mean discomfort count for different positions when the subjects were asked to compare a pair of non-uniform stimuli, or 6.6%–12.4% for different spatial frequency of the stimuli. Using a large number of human subjects could counteract the variances of human performance, for example, 32–35 subjects were used by Eble-Hankins and Waters,13 and 67 participants were used at each test trial in this study.

The average glare ratings were then used for testing the predictability of UGR, CGI, BGI, and VCP for evaluating common non-uniform electric glare sources. Figure 7 compares the average subjective ratings of G1, G2, G3, and G1G2G3 jointly, to the calculated values found using numerical methods without sub-division (N = 1). The glare ratings without sub-division were adopted because human eyes view a discomfort glare source, often presented in the periphery of the visual field, always as a whole, rather than as sub-divisions.

The data were further analysed with SPSS using ANOVA. The p-values for interpreting the differences between the average subjective ratings and calculated ratings were calculated for UGR as p = 0.003 (louvred surfaces) and 0.006 (paper-covered surfaces), CGI (0.001, 0.002), BGI (0.002, 0.001), and VCP (0.000, 0.000). Since the p-values are all less than 0.05, there is significant difference between the calculated glare ratings and the subjective ratings. Conclusively, the existing formulae of UGR, CGI, BGI and VCP, when aided by the HDR photogrammetry and numerical analysis to evaluate the non-uniform electric light sources, fail to predict the actual glare sensations that young people may feel. All indices overestimated the glare sensation from non-uniform light sources. On the other hand, the very low p-values (i.e., 0.000–0.006) obtained for all glare indices from both louvred and paper-covered surfaces indicate that this failure is independent of the non-uniformity level of the glaring surfaces.

sec.title: 7. Conclusions and discussion
sec.p: In daily life, non-uniform light distribution on non-luminous or light-emitting surfaces is everywhere. Technically, only a constant light level across a surface or an entire scene can be claimed to be a uniform light distribution, which may exist only in a laboratory. In practice, any light distribution where an observer fails to detect luminance variation could be treated as uniform, which is still rare. According to Ricco’s, Weber’s, and Bloch’s laws,62 the human eyes’ threshold luminance contrast depends on the adaptation luminance of the field, the recognition time, and the target area. There is no standard threshold luminance contrast value, which could be useful for the lighting industry to define a non-uniform surface.

Lighting researchers has been working on discomfort glare from common non-uniform light sources for over 80 years, yet still without a satisfactory assessment method. There are many causes of this difficulty, including the unsuitability of conventional luminance meters for measurement of non-uniform light. HDR photogrammetry,49 which represents the next generation of technology for mapping non-uniform light, can help break through the bottleneck. With the aid of the HDR photogrammetry, the acquired synchronous luminance and geometry data of an entire scene at pixel level could help restart the fundamental research of discomfort glare via numerical analyses.

As a beginning, this study looked into the appropriateness of the most used UGR, CGI, BGI, and VCP methods for predicting discomfort glare for real non-uniform lighting, using a single well-controlled test scenario in a laboratory, although this may not be a typical lighting installation. In addition, our daily environments have a wide variety of layouts of glare sources over the FOV, a single test scenario is insufficient to address all of them. Different test settings are necessary to test the additivity and sub-divisibility of glare sensation of multiple discrete glare sources. In fact, the Guth position index p has its own limitations and cannot cover all possible cases of practical luminaire layouts. The CIE19 recommended a “good” range of d and s values (i.e., d = 0.75–12.0, s = 0.0–6.0 in Table C-2) likely to be of importance in practice. Outside this range, large variations of glare sensation may be expected that the formulae of UGR, CGI, BGI, and VCP may fail to recognize, yet further experimentation is needed. This study was not aimed to find a one-size-fits-all solution, which is impossible, but to be a good start for this type of research with the aid of HDR photogrammetry. The layout of glare sources used in this study (d = 2.60–7.26, s = 0.03–2.83) falls inside the CIE’s recommended range and thus was a good example of practice. However, the outcomes of this test should not be used to interpret different conditions out of the examined d, s range (i.e., d = 2.60–7.26, s = 0.03–2.83).

To draw a conclusion, the existing formulae of UGR, CGI, BGI, and VCP, even when aided by HDR photogrammetry, are inappropriate for evaluating non-uniform electric light sources via numerical method, within a good range of position indices d = 2.60–7.26, s = 0.03–2.83. Further validations using more types of non-uniform light sources, including natural light, are needed.

Besides well-controlled interior electric lighting, HDR photogrammetry and numerical analysis could be used for evaluating real-time daylighting, exterior area lighting, and roadway and traffic lighting as well. However, the current study has two limitations that might make such applications difficult. First, averaging out the projected area and solid angle sub-tense of a single glaring luminous element at pixel level using equation (24) is only a short-cut solution. It may be not applicable to large non-uniform glare sources, such as windows, on the periphery of the FOV. Ideally, a computer software program can calculate the projected area of every single pixel from the acquired XYZ coordinates of this pixel and neighbouring pixels. The program is now under development in the University of Kansas Lighting Research Laboratory. Second, the calibration and computation workloads associated with the HDR photogrammetry are tremendous. Calculations of discomfort glare from non-uniform light sources via numerical analysis on Excel spreadsheets are also laborious. Supporting computer software programs are desired, which are under development, and will speed up data treatments.
